inference:
At Stage 1, the area of the rectangle is $3\times 3=9$ square inches.

At Stage 2, the area of the rectangle is $(3+3)\times 3=18$ square inches.

At Stage 3, the area of the rectangle is $(3+3+3)\times 3=27$ square inches.

At Stage 4, the area of the rectangle is $(3+3+3+3)\times 3=36$ square inches.

At Stage 5, the area of the rectangle is $(3+3+3+3+3)\times 3=45$ square inches.

At Stage 6, the area of the rectangle is $(3+3+3+3+3+3)\times 3=54$ square inches.
Final Answer: $\boxed{54}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: The number of squares in the rectangles is an arithmetic sequence with first term 1 and common difference 1. Thus, at Stage 6, there will be 6 squares. Since each square has an area of $3 \cdot 3 = 9$ square inches, the total area of the rectangle at Stage 6 is $6 \cdot 9 = \boxed{54}$ square inches.
